title: Installer: treat ast-grep as required (auto-install by default)
description: The project depends on ast-grep for accurate JS/TS scanning. Today install.sh can leave users without ast-grep (especially in non-interactive runs), forcing UBS into regex/heuristic fallback and generating false positives. Make ast-grep installation the default, and make skipping it an explicit opt-out.
design:
Current behavior (problem):
- If ast-grep is missing, install.sh warns and prompts. In non-interactive contexts the prompt can default to 'no', leaving users in regex fallback mode.

Desired behavior:
- If --skip-ast-grep is NOT set and ast-grep is missing, installer should install it automatically in:
  - --easy-mode
  - --non-interactive
- In fully interactive mode, prompt is OK, but default should strongly encourage install (and the UI should make clear that fallback is inaccurate for TSX).

Security considerations:
- Prefer package manager install (brew/apt/dnf) when available.
- Fallback to downloading a pinned GitHub release asset (already implemented) is acceptable.

User experience:
- After install, print 'ast-grep available at …' and verify 'ast-grep --version' and 'ast-grep scan -h' if possible.
acceptance_criteria: - Running install.sh on a fresh machine (no ast-grep) results in ast-grep being installed unless --skip-ast-grep is set.\n- Non-interactive installs do NOT silently skip ast-grep.\n- Installer output clearly communicates that ast-grep is required for accurate JS/TS scanning.

title: modules/ubs-js.sh: fail fast (env error) instead of regex fallback on TS/TSX
description: When ast-grep isn't usable, the JS module prints 'regex fallback mode' and continues, which can explode into dozens of false positives on TSX/TypeScript syntax. Change default behavior: if TS/TSX/JSX is present and no AST engine is available, stop and return an explicit environment error.
design:
Policy (to be aligned with the degraded-mode contract):
- Detect whether the target tree contains any .ts/.tsx/.jsx/.mjs files (or whether INCLUDE_EXT includes ts/tsx).
- If TSX/TS is detected and ast-grep is not available/working, exit with code 2 and a concise message.
- The message should explain that continuing would be inaccurate, and provide next steps (install.sh, install ast-grep, or ubs doctor --fix if available).
- Optional escape hatch (only if contract says so): UBS_ALLOW_REGEX_FALLBACK=1 or --allow-regex-fallback.

Why this is NOT reducing coverage:
- This doesn't remove checks; it prevents running an inaccurate engine that produces noise. Users get a deterministic failure instead of misleading results.
acceptance_criteria: - In a TS/TSX codebase with no ast-grep available, modules/ubs-js.sh exits with code 2 and does not emit CRITICAL/WARNING findings.\n- In a JS-only codebase, existing regex fallback behavior may remain (or be explicitly controlled by contract).

title: JS/TS: fix global-pollution heuristic false positives (JSX props, default params, TS syntax)
description: The 'Global variable assignments' detector in modules/ubs-js.sh uses a regex-based Python heuristic that can misinterpret valid TS/TSX syntax (multiline JSX props and default parameters) as top-level assignments, producing bogus criticals/warnings.
design:
Observed FP classes (from user reports + current heuristic structure):
- Multiline JSX attributes: lines like 'prop={x}' can match an assignment regex when scanned out of JSX context.
- Function parameter defaults on separate lines: lines like 'a = 1,' inside multi-line parameter lists can look like assignments.
- TypeScript type syntax and generics can confuse simplistic regex tokenization.

Mitigation strategy (keep detection surface area):
- Improve the heuristic to correctly ignore syntactic regions that cannot represent a real implicit-global assignment:
  - Track when we're inside a JSX opening tag spanning multiple lines (state machine: enter on '<Component' without closing '>', exit when '>' encountered). Skip scanning lines while inside.
  - Track when we're inside a function/method parameter list spanning multiple lines (enter after 'function foo(' / '(...):' patterns, exit at matching ')'). Skip scanning parameter-list lines for 'name = …' patterns.
  - Continue to flag true suspicious assignments that are statements/expressions in code regions.

Optional (if ast-grep is guaranteed):
- Where feasible, replace line-regex matching with AST-based matching to identify assignment expressions and then apply lightweight scope heuristics (e.g., ignore inside parameter nodes / JSX nodes).

Regression anchors:
- Extend existing fixtures (no new files if possible):
  - test-suite/frameworks/react/clean-component.jsx: add multiline props
  - test-suite/js/type_narrowing/clean/safe-narrowing.ts: add multiline default params
  Both should NOT produce global-pollution findings.
acceptance_criteria: - UBS no longer reports global-pollution findings for multiline JSX props or multiline default params in TS/TSX fixtures.\n- The detector still flags real suspicious assignments (add/keep at least one fixture example that should remain detected).

title: JS/TS: AST-confirm high-severity regex findings before reporting
description: Even with ast-grep installed, some UBS JS checks are regex/heuristic-based and can produce false positives on TS/TSX syntax. For the highest-severity findings (CRITICAL/WARNING), add a lightweight AST confirmation step so we only report matches that correspond to real syntax nodes.
design:
Principle:
- Regex remains a fast candidate generator. AST is the validator.

Initial scope (target the worst offenders):
- Global pollution detector candidates
- Any regex patterns known to misfire in TSX (as identified in the FP inventory)

Implementation idea:
- When ast-grep is available, for each candidate location (file+line), use ast-grep JSON output to verify an appropriate node exists at/near that span (assignment_expression / binary_expression / call_expression, etc.).
- Drop candidates that occur in JSX attribute context, type-only syntax, or parameter default lists (these are common FP zones).

Performance:
- Keep bounded: only validate up to N candidates per rule, or validate only when candidate count exceeds a threshold, so we don't explode runtime.

Why this preserves coverage:
- We keep the same patterns, but stop reporting syntactically-impossible matches.
acceptance_criteria: - For at least one high-severity rule class that previously produced TSX false positives, UBS output drops the bogus findings while still flagging real occurrences in fixtures.\n- Runtime impact stays within an acceptable budget (define in implementation: e.g., <10% overhead on medium repos).

title: modules/ubs-js.sh: honor UBS_AST_GREP_BIN for AST engine
description: To enable ubs-level tool caching (and avoid PATH issues), the JS module should accept an explicit ast-grep binary path via env var and use it preferentially when valid.
design:
Design:
- If UBS_AST_GREP_BIN is set and executable, use it as AST_GREP_CMD[0].
- Validate it's actually ast-grep (e.g., ' --version' contains 'ast-grep').
- Continue existing discovery order as fallback: ast-grep → sg (verified) → npx @ast-grep/cli.
- When running in CI, print a clear one-liner stating which AST engine is active (path/cmd).

Why:
- Prevents scenarios where install.sh did install ast-grep but PATH isn't updated in the shell/CI runner, so UBS silently degrades.
- Enables meta-runner to supply a verified ast-grep without touching user dotfiles or system PATH.
acceptance_criteria: - With UBS_AST_GREP_BIN pointing to a valid ast-grep binary, the module uses it even if PATH doesn't contain ast-grep.\n- If the env var points to a non-ast-grep binary, the module refuses it and falls back with a clear warning.

title: JS/TS: guarantee AST scanning + eliminate TSX regex-fallback false positives
description: When UBS runs on TS/TSX projects it can fall back to regex/heuristic scanning and produce large numbers of false positives (e.g., multiline JSX attributes and default parameters misread as assignments/comparisons). This epic makes JS/TS scanning syntax-aware by default (ast-grep always available/used) and defines a strict degraded-mode policy so we never spam users with bogus CRITICAL/WARNING counts.
design:
Background:
- Real-world report: TypeScript + ESLint + build all pass, but UBS reports dozens of CRITICAL/WARNING that are all false positives caused by regex/heuristic fallback mis-parsing TSX/TypeScript syntax.

Goals:
- Make AST analysis the default/expected path for JS/TS (esp. TSX).
- Ensure ast-grep is reliably available (installer + runtime self-healing).
- If AST cannot run, fail fast with a clear 'environment misconfigured' message (no noisy findings).
- Keep UBS detection surface area: avoid weakening/turning off checks; instead make them syntax-aware or verified.

Non-goals:
- Replacing ESLint/tsc (UBS remains a fast bug-pattern scanner).
- Over-engineering full semantic type analysis for every rule (use targeted confirmation where it pays off).

Key UX principle:
- Users should never see 100+ bogus CRITICAL/WARNING because a dependency is missing. Missing AST engine should look like a tooling error, not a code-quality catastrophe.
acceptance_criteria: - On a TSX project, UBS uses ast-grep-powered scanning by default (no 'regex fallback' spam).\n- If ast-grep is unavailable/unusable, UBS exits with an explicit environment error and remediation instructions.\n- New regression tests cover the previously common FP patterns (multiline JSX props, default params) so we never regress.

title: Spec: JS/TS degraded-mode policy when AST engine is unavailable
description: Define the contract for how UBS behaves when JS/TS scanning cannot use a syntax-aware engine (ast-grep or equivalent). The goal is: never emit large bogus CRITICAL/WARNING counts from regex fallback; treat missing AST as an environment error with clear remediation.
design:
Key questions to answer:
- What is the minimum required AST capability for JS/TS?
  - ast-grep binary present?
  - does it support 'scan'?
  - does it successfully parse TS/TSX in the target repo?
- When AST is missing/unusable, what happens?
  - Default: fail fast with an explicit environment error (recommended).
  - Optional escape hatch: allow regex fallback only behind an explicit flag/env var (for air-gapped/offline scenarios).
- Exit code semantics (important for CI):
  - 0: clean
  - 1: findings (critical/warning depending on flags)
  - 2: environment/dependency failure (missing ast-grep, parse engine unavailable)
- UX requirements for the error path:
  - Single concise banner explaining: 'JS/TS requires ast-grep; current run would be inaccurate; refusing to run in fallback mode.'
  - One-line fix suggestions: run install.sh, or install ast-grep, or run ubs doctor --fix (if implemented).

Deliverable:
- Documented in this issue (and later mirrored into README once implemented).
acceptance_criteria: - Contract explicitly specifies default behavior, exit codes, and the opt-in escape hatch (if any).\n- Implementation tasks can reference this contract as the source of truth.

title: JS/TS: inventory TS/TSX false positives + map to scanners
description: Before changing behavior, build a precise map from reported false positives to the exact UBS JS module checks that emitted them (regex/heuristic vs ast-grep). This prevents us from fixing the wrong layer and accidentally reducing real bug coverage.
design:
What to capture:
- Minimal TS/TSX snippets that trigger each false positive class (default params, multiline JSX props/attributes, TS type syntax, comparisons inside JSX, generics, etc.).
- Which UBS JS checks fired (category + subheader text + grep/AST rule).
- Whether the finding came from: ripgrep/grep regex, python heuristic, ast-grep rule pack, or tsserver/type-narrowing helpers.

Why this matters:
- Some checks run even when ast-grep is installed; others only run in fallback mode. Fixes must be targeted so we don't mute legitimate detections.

Deliverable:
- A short writeup attached as comments on this issue with examples + source locations in modules/ubs-js.sh.
acceptance_criteria: - For each FP cluster, we have a concrete snippet and identify the emitting UBS check (category/subheader) and mechanism (regex/python/ast-grep).\n- At least one safe mitigation is proposed per cluster (AST gating, better parsing, masking, etc.)

title: Tests: JS module exits with env-error (2) when AST engine missing on TSX
description: Once we adopt 'fail fast instead of regex fallback' for TS/TSX without ast-grep, add a regression test to ensure this behavior stays stable (correct exit code + message).
design:
Challenge:
- CI/dev machines running the suite typically have ast-grep installed, so we need a deterministic way to simulate 'ast-grep unavailable'.

Options:
1) Add a test-only env var (e.g., UBS_TEST_FORCE_NO_AST_GREP=1) in modules/ubs-js.sh check_ast_grep() to force HAS_AST_GREP=0.
2) Run the module under a sanitized PATH and with npx disabled; but this is brittle because it can also hide rg/python.

Preferred:
- Option 1 (explicit test hook) because it's deterministic and only active in tests.

Test behavior:
- Run modules/ubs-js.sh against a fixture dir that contains .ts/.tsx/.jsx and set UBS_TEST_FORCE_NO_AST_GREP=1.
- Assert exit code 2 and that output includes the remediation guidance.

title: ubs doctor: verify ast-grep availability (and fix if tool cache exists)
description: Add explicit ast-grep diagnostics to 'ubs doctor' so users can quickly understand whether JS/TS scanning will be accurate. Optionally support --fix to download ast-grep into the tool cache when missing.
design:
Current gap:
- 'ubs doctor' verifies module checksums but does not validate external dependencies like ast-grep. Users can end up in regex fallback mode without noticing until they see noisy findings.

Proposed doctor checks:
- Detect ast-grep engine availability in priority order:
  1) user-provided UBS_AST_GREP_BIN (if we add it)
  2) ast-grep/sg in PATH
  3) tool-cache ast-grep (if implemented)
- Verify it actually works:
  - '<cmd> --version' contains 'ast-grep'
  - '<cmd> scan -h' succeeds (ensures rule-pack mode available)

If --fix is requested:
- If tool-cache auto-provisioning is implemented, download/refresh ast-grep and re-verify.

UX:
- The doctor output should include the resolved command and a clear PASS/FAIL for JS/TS AST readiness.
acceptance_criteria: - 'ubs doctor' reports a clear ast-grep readiness line and the resolved binary path/cmd.\n- If --fix is supported, 'ubs doctor --fix' installs/refreshes ast-grep and re-checks successfully.

title: ubs: standardize exit code 2 as 'environment error' and surface it nicely
description: If language modules adopt exit code 2 for dependency/environment failures (e.g., JS module refusing TSX fallback without ast-grep), the ubs meta-runner should recognize and report it distinctly from 'findings' failures.
design:
Design:
- Define in ubs: exit code 2 from a module means 'scanner could not run correctly' (missing dependency, parse engine not available, etc.).
- When any module returns 2:
  - print a concise summary naming the module(s) and showing their stderr guidance
  - exit 2 (or 1 if we want to keep CI simple; contract should decide)
  - avoid merging partial/empty JSON in a misleading way

Why:
- CI systems and humans need to distinguish 'your code has bugs' from 'the scanner environment is broken'.
- Prevents false failures and makes remediation obvious.
acceptance_criteria: - When the JS module exits 2, ubs exits 2 and prints a clear message pointing to the missing dependency/remediation steps.\n- ubs does not report bogus totals in this scenario.

title: ubs: auto-provision ast-grep via verified tool cache
description: Users may run the standalone ubs script without install.sh (e.g., CI curl-download). To prevent JS/TS runs from silently degrading into regex/heuristic mode, teach the ubs meta-runner to download a pinned ast-grep release into a local tool cache and verify it before use.
design:
Approach:
- Add an internal tool cache directory (e.g., /ubs/tools).
- Detect platform+arch and select a pinned ast-grep release asset.
- Embed expected SHA256 for each supported asset in ubs (similar to MODULE_CHECKSUMS).
- Download only when missing or checksum mismatch; verify before executing.
- Export an env var (e.g., UBS_AST_GREP_BIN=/path/to/ast-grep) so language modules can use it without relying on PATH mutations.

Why ubs-level vs install.sh-level:
- install.sh is great for interactive onboarding, but CI and 'download ubs only' workflows are common.
- This keeps the scanning pipeline self-contained and makes failures deterministic.

Constraints / safety:
- Fail closed if verification fails.
- Never overwrite a user-installed ast-grep; prefer it if present and usable.

Notes:
- This is designed so we can later extend to other dependencies (jq/rg) if desired, but scope here is ast-grep only.
acceptance_criteria: - On a machine with no ast-grep, running 'ubs --only=js <repo>' results in ast-grep being downloaded into the tool cache and used.\n- If download or checksum verification fails, ubs exits with an explicit environment error (no bogus findings).\n- A user-installed ast-grep in PATH continues to take precedence if it works.
